decisions.title: The Schedule Problem
decisions.scenario: You‚Äôre a student-athlete with practices 5 days a week. You also need money for basics (food, rides, school stuff). A local job offers you 18 hours/week at $15/hr, but it conflicts with practice twice a week. Your coach says attendance matters for playing time.
decisions.context_info: For student-athletes, time is a budget. Every hour you add has a cost: grades, sleep, and performance. The best move usually keeps you eligible, healthy, and consistent‚Äîeven if it‚Äôs not the most money immediately.

choices.label: üí™ Take the 18 hrs/week job and make it work

immediate_outcome.text: You hustle. Your bank balance grows fast and you feel independent. But you‚Äôre exhausted and start arriving late to practice.

delayed_consequence.text: You miss two practices in a row during a busy week. Your coach benches you for a game. You feel embarrassed and your motivation drops. Schoolwork starts slipping too.
delayed_consequence.why: Overcommitting can create a domino effect: sleep loss ‚Üí worse performance ‚Üí fewer opportunities. Consistency is often more valuable than short-term money.

immediate_outcome.text: You ask for fewer hours and keep practice as a priority. You earn less, but your schedule feels sustainable.

delayed_consequence.text: Because you stay consistent, you get more playing time. A teacher also recommends you for a small scholarship opportunity. You‚Äôre not rich, but you‚Äôre stable.

decisions.title: Eligibility on the Line
decisions.scenario: Midterms hit hard. Your grades start dropping. You need a minimum GPA to stay eligible for sports and for a potential scholarship. You also need money, and your job wants you to take extra shifts.
decisions.context_info: Eligibility is an invisible asset. Losing it can cost scholarships, team placement, and future opportunities. The smartest choice protects your long-term options even if it costs short-term money.

choices.label: üïí Take extra shifts and hope grades recover later

immediate_outcome.text: You earn more money and feel relieved about expenses. But you lose study time and fall further behind.

delayed_consequence.text: Your GPA drops below the requirement. You lose eligibility for postseason play and a scholarship lead disappears. You regret it because the money didn‚Äôt last‚Äîbut the missed opportunity does.
delayed_consequence.why: Some losses aren‚Äôt financial at first. When you lose eligibility, you lose doors that can change your long-term trajectory.

choices.label: üìö Cut work hours temporarily and get academic support

immediate_outcome.text: You reduce shifts and use tutoring / office hours. It‚Äôs stressful financially, but you feel your grades stabilize.

delayed_consequence.text: You bring your GPA back up and stay eligible. You get a strong recommendation from a teacher. You didn‚Äôt earn as much, but your future got bigger.
delayed_consequence.why: When your long-term options depend on grades, short-term sacrifice can be the highest ROI choice you can make.

choices.label: üßæ Apply for assistance + reduce expenses instead of working more

immediate_outcome.text: You explore help programs (food pantry, campus/community resources) and adjust spending. It feels awkward, but it reduces pressure.

delayed_consequence.text: You avoid burnout, keep your grades stable, and still cover necessities. You learn that support systems exist‚Äîand using them is a strategy, not a failure.
delayed_consequence.why: Community resources reduce the need to overwork. Less stress can improve performance in both school and sports.

decisions.title: The ‚ÄòSmall‚Äô Purchase That Snowballs
decisions.scenario: Your teammates all have new shoes and gear. You want to fit in and perform well. You don‚Äôt have much saved, but you get offered a store credit card with '10% off today.'
decisions.context_info: Store cards can be tempting because the discount feels like free money. But high interest and missed payments can hurt your credit‚Äîmaking future goals (apartment, car, loans) harder.

choices.label: üõçÔ∏è Get the store card for the discount

immediate_outcome.text: You get the shoes and feel confident. The discount makes it feel smart. You tell yourself you‚Äôll pay it off quickly.

delayed_consequence.text: You miss a payment during a busy month. Late fees hit and your score drops. You feel embarrassed and stressed because now you‚Äôre paying extra for shoes you already wore.
delayed_consequence.why: High interest + fees punish inconsistent cash flow. A small purchase can become expensive when payments slip.

choices.label: üíµ Buy a cheaper pair now and save for the rest

choices.label: ü§ù Ask about team support / secondhand gear options

delayed_consequence.text: You realize community + asking questions can solve money problems faster than debt. You build confidence and stay focused on performance.
delayed_consequence.why: Social strategies (asking, sharing resources) can reduce financial pressure and protect credit.

decisions.title: Summer Money Decision
decisions.scenario: You have the summer off from school schedules, but training still exists. You can either grind a full-time job, do an internship with lower pay, or focus on training and school prep.
decisions.context_info: Summer choices matter because they affect resumes, scholarships, and future earnings. A lower-paying internship can have higher long-term ROI than a higher-paying job with no growth.

immediate_outcome.text: You stack money quickly and feel secure. But you‚Äôre tired and your training consistency drops.

delayed_consequence.text: You have money, but you missed the chance to build your resume. When internship applications open, you feel behind and stressed.
delayed_consequence.why: Cash helps now, but experience can multiply your future earnings. A balance is ideal, but choosing only money can limit growth.

choices.label: üßë‚Äçüíº Take the internship even if it pays less

immediate_outcome.text: You earn less today, but you gain skills, references, and confidence. Your time feels purposeful.

delayed_consequence.text: Your resume stands out. You‚Äôre offered another opportunity the next year. You feel like you‚Äôre building something long-term.
delayed_consequence.why: Experience compounds. A strong internship can increase future earnings far more than one summer of higher pay.

immediate_outcome.text: You create a balanced schedule: part-time income, consistent training, and time to learn a new skill.

delayed_consequence.text: You enter the school year stable and prepared. You didn‚Äôt max money or max resume‚Äîbut you built a sustainable base.
delayed_consequence.why: A balanced plan protects health and creates steady progress. Sustainability is a competitive advantage.
